Alternatively referred to as the 'Iconical British Zoology', ‘British Zoology Illustrated’, (or similar) or the 3rd edition.

bibl.title: Supplement to the Arctic Zoology.
bibl.note: Printed by Henry Hughs. viii + 163 pages with marked sections for supplements to the introduction and volumes I and II. From the advertisement: ‘I have been often reproached for not giving a map with the Arctic Zoology. I have now complied with the desire: and given two’ (v). No illustrations in the Supplement apart from the maps. For Richard Bull's extra-illustration of the Supplement, see Evans, 'Richard Bull and Thomas Pennant', 191 n. 66.

bibl.title: Arctic Zoology. Vol. I. Introduction. Class I. Quadrupeds; Vol. II. Class II. Birds. III. Reptiles. IV. Fish. V. Insects.
bibl.note: Volumes I and II published separately. For Richard Bull's extra-illustrated copy, see Evans, 'Richard Bull and Thomas Pennant', 280–1, 291, nn. 66, 67; Sotheby's Sale Catalogue, 28 June 1926, Lot 208.

bibl.title: Arctic zoology (2nd edn.)
bibl.note: 3 vols.: Vol. I: Introduction to the Arctic zoology, Vol. II: Arctic zoology. Vol. I. Class I. Quadrupeds. II. Birds, Vol. III: Arctic zoology. Vol. II. Class II. Birds. III. Reptiles. IV. Fish. V. Insects. Note, however, that the second edition is often referred to in the Pennant-Bull correspondence and in bibliographic records as a two-volume work, discarding the Introduction to the Arctic zoology, and numbering the subsequent two volumes as I and II. This convention has been followed in the current edition, too. On Bull's large paper copy of the second edition, see Evans, 'Richard Bull and Thomas Pennant', 281–2.

bibl.title: A Description of Three Hundred Animals; viz. beasts, birds, fishes, serpents, and insects. With a particular account of the whale-fishery. Extracted out of the best authors, and adapted to the use of all capacities ... Illustrated with copper plates, etc.
'Introduction of the Arctic World'
bibl.note: This was published in Arctic Zoology. Vol. I. Introduction. Class I. Quadrupeds (1784), pp. I–CCV. Pennant's extra-illustration of the 'Introduction' expanded to four volumes of his 'Outlines of the Globe', preserved at NMM. See further HPWaH, p. 319; and Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant', pp. 622–7, which gives a description of the contents of vols. I to IV of this deposit, describing them at p. 626 as an 'enlarged version of the first half of the introduction of [Pennant's] Arctic Zoology' and noting that the second half, which should have taken up vol. V, was never completed. Richard Bull apparently extra-illustrated a large paper copy of this work. See 1122.

bibl.title: Indian Zoology
bibl.note: English and French, 12 coloured plates, with descriptive letterpress. The 'Advertisement' describes this as a collaborative project, in which Pennant took on the work of providing the descriptive text, and the cost of engraving and publishing the plates was shared between him, Joseph Banks and John Gideon Loten. References in Pennant's correspondence with Richard Bull suggest that he was working on an introduction to *Indian zoology* during 1786, but when a second edition appeared in 1791, Pennant again described it as a collaborative work (since he had 'myself abjured all future publications'), the main addition to the first edition resting on a translation from the German and Latin of a 1781 edition by Johann Reinhold Forster. The work on Indian zoology carried out from 1786 was incorporated in The view of Hindoostan. Vol. I. Western Hindoostan (1798). See Evans, 'The life and work of Thomas Pennant', p. 162; and for the 2nd edn., Indian Zoology (1790 [1791]).

bibl.title: Macclesfield collection of manuscripts
bibl.note: The Macclesfield collection of manuscripts (now NLW, Llanstephan 1–154) constitute the collection of father and son Samuel and Moses Williams, and came to the possession of George Parker, second earl of Macclesfield, through hi connection with the mathermatician William Jones. Use was made of them by the editors of The Myvyrian Archaiology of Wales, to whom the third volume of 1807 was dedicated. The manuscript remained at Shirburn Castle, Oxfordshire, until 1899. Geraint H. Jenkins, Ffion Mair Jones and David Ceri Jones (eds.), The Correspondence of Iolo Morganwg, 3 vols. (Cardiff: University of Wales Press, 2007), p. 547 n. 3; Daniel Huws, Repertory of Welsh Manuscripts and Scribes (Aberystwyth: Centre for Advanced Welsh and Celtic Studies, forthcoming).

bibl.note: A manuscript held at Badminton, Somerset, home of Henry Beaufort, fifth duke of Beaufort, and described as the 'Badminton Book' was in discussion by antiquaries including Pennant, John Price and Richard Gough during 1776. It apparently contained drawings of Welsh buildings and landscapes. For material copied by Pennant from Beaufort's collection see Paul Evans, 'Thomas Pennant (1726–1798): "The Father of Cambrian tourists" ', WHR, vol. 13, no. 4 (1987), 395–417; esp. 411 n. 59; NLW 2568E.

Pennant's travel in northern England continued beyond the confines of this volume: for an extra-illustrated manuscript version of his tour 'From Alston Moor to Harrowgate', the opening of which reads 'I now resume the tour which I had left unfinished at Alston Moor p. 234 of vol. bibl.title: 'A journey from London to Dover'

Discussion in the Bull-Pennant correspondence of work by Pennant's secretary on producing manuscript copies of the text suggests that Bull's extra-illustration of his version would have started during the summer of 1790 or later. See 1099, 1105. For the posthumous publication of this journey, see From London to Dover (1801).

bibl.title: Stanley pedigree
bibl.note: Extensive genealogical material relating to the Stanley family is given in John Seacome, History of the House of Stanley, from the Conquest to the death of the Right Honorable Edward, late Earl of Derby, in 1776. Containing a Genealogical and Historical Account, of that Illustrious House. To which is added, A Description of the Isle of Man (Preston: E. Sergent, 1793). Given under various headings from p. 422, they include 'Genealogia Præclaræ et Antiquæ Familiæ de Stanley', pp. 424–31; 'The Pedigree and Posterity of Sir Thomas Stanley, Second son of Sir John Stanley the first, by Isabel de Latham', pp. 432–5; 'The Genealogy and Issue of Sir John Stanley II', pp. 436–8; 'The Genealogy and Posterity of Peter Stanley, Esquire, Second son of Sir William Stanley, of Hooton, by Ann, the daughter of Sir James Harrington', pp. 439–43. The volume was first published under the title Memoirs; containing a genealogical and historical account of the ancient and honourable house of Stanley: from the conquest to the death of James late Earl of Derby, in the year 1735; as also a full description of the Isle of Man, &c (Liverpool: A. Sadler, [1741]).

bibl.title: Antiquae linguae Britannicae … dictionarium duplex
Salusbury pedigree book
bibl.note: The Salusbury pedigree book was kept at Wynnstay (but destroyed by a fire there in 1858). Transcripts from it by Angharad Llwyd are found in NLW 1598D; the best preserved copy is in Wynnstay 143-4. Daniel Huws, 'Repertory of Welsh Manuscripts and Scribes' (forthcoming), AB.NLW, p. 70. Pennant noted that it was in the possession of Sir Watkin Williams Wynn, 'who favored me with the loan of it', and described it as 'contain[ing] the pedigrees of all the gentlemen in North Wales, and of some adjacent counties, with their arms finely illuminated'. A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778), I, pp. 451–2.

bibl.note: Described as 'aesthetically pleasing', this four-volume work by Joseph Frederick Wallet Des Barres (1721–1824) included charts and views of Nova Scotia, New England, the Gulf of St Lawrence and the coast south of New York. ODNB; here [accessed 24 January 2019].

Chester Chronicle
bibl.note: Established in 1775, the Chester Chronicle was a conduit for the expression of radical ideas in Cheshire and north Wales during the 1790s. See Löffler, Welsh Responses to the French Revolution, p. 137, and for digital copies, see here [accessed 20 December 2018].

bibl.note: Pennant's 'circuit' of the Isle of Wight, to which he refers as the culmination of a journey from Dover along the coast of Kent, Sussex, and Hampshire, formed a part of 'Outlines of the Globe'. See HPWaH, p. 322.

'Literary life'
bibl.note: The literary life of the late Thomas Pennant, Esq., by himself was copied in manuscript form several times before its publication in 1793. See NLW 5501E, signed by Pennant and dated 1 March 1790; the draft at NLW 2569C; and the copies extra-illustrated by Richard Bull and Pennant himself (NLW 5502E, signed and dated 1 March 1790 by Pennant; NLW 12706E).

bibl.title: Missals at Mostyn library
bibl.note: A note in HPWaH, p. 80, states of Mostyn library that 'There are moreover a variety of beautiful missals, all on vellum, and superbly illuminated. One as old as the year 1200; and many very curious Bibles'. A Royal Commission report on the collection noted that it included examples of the service book of the Roman Catholic church, the book of hours, the Order of the Mass, the Office of the Blessed Virgin Mary, and the Vetus missal. Fourth Report of the Royal Commission on Historical Manuscripts. Part I. Report and appendix (London, 1874), pp. 347–52, 354, 356.

bibl.title: The plays of William Shakespeare: accurately printed from the text of the corrected copy left by the late George Steevens [sic]: with a series of engravings, from original designs of Henry Fuseli, and a selection of explanatory and historical notes, from the most eminent commentators; a history of the stage, a life of Shakespeare, &c

bibl.title: Introduction to the Arctic zoology
bibl.note: The Introduction to the Arctic zoology was the first of three volumes issued by Faulder as a second edition of Arctic zoology in 1792. Most bibliographic records, as well as the Pennant-Bull correspondence, however, refer to it by its separate title, reserving the numbers I and II for the remainder of the text.

The Robert ap Huw manuscript
bibl.addName: Mr Morris's Book; MS of ancient British Music
bibl.note: The Robert ap Huw manuscript (BL Add. 14905), copied c. 1613, was in the possession of Lewis Morris in 1742 and of his brother Richard in 1771. It contains late medieval harp music ('cerdd dant') written in tablature notation, notoriously difficult to interpret. See here [accessed 10 September 2019] for hyperlinks to a facsimile copy of the manuscript and to P. D. Whittaker, 'British Museum, Additional MS 14905; An interpretation and re-examination of the music and text' (unpublished University of Wales, Bangor, MA thesis, 1974). For a reference by Pennant to this manuscript, see A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778), I, p. 429, n.

bibl.title: A dissertation on the rise, union, and power, the progressions, separations and corruptions of poetry and music

Iter Boreale
bibl.note: Thomas Master's Iter Boreale was a prose and verse account of a journey from Montgomeryshire to Lincolnshire, where he was to be inducted into the living of East Wickham. Written in the form of a letter to his father, dated September 1637, it was edited by his companion on this journey, George Ent, and posthumously published in 1675. ODNB.

bibl.title: Collections
bibl.note: Collections amounting to eighty-five volumes made by the antiquary Roger Dodsworth (bap. 1585, d. 1654) were bequeathed to the Bodleian Library in 1673 by his friend Charles Fairfax, a son of the first Lord Fairfax. See ODNB; and Bodleian Library, Dodsworth Manuscripts, here [accessed 16 September 2019].

bibl.title: 'Gosteg yr Halen'
bibl.note: 'Gosteg yr Halen' ('The Prelude of the Salt') is one of the tunes named in the Robert ap Huw manuscript, where it is stated that it was played on the 'Mac Mwn byr' measure, and performed in the presence of Arthur's knights when the salt-cellar was placed on the table. See 'Appendix I: Robert ap Huw Tables I–IV', 'Table I: The musical items in the Robert ap Huw manuscript (Lbl MS Add. 14905)', in Welsh Music History 3: Robert ap Huw Studies, ed. by Sally Harper (Cardiff: University of Wales Press, 1999), pp. 318–21, esp. 318, 320 n. 5.

bibl.title: Regiam Majestatem
bibl.note: The earliest surviving digest of Scottish laws: thought to be written in the early fourteenth-century and in print from the early seventeenth-century. It was erroneously attributed to David I of Scotland.
